ch.xelaalex.fuzzle

Class Searcher

  • java.lang.Object
    • ch.xelaalex.fuzzle.Searcher

  • public class Searcher
extends java.lang.Object
    This Class contains logic to find Values that fit to a String, i.e. find Movies according to a Search String.
    Version:
    1.1
    Author:
    XelaaleX1234

    • Method Detail

      • find

        public static java.util.Collection<Option> find(java.util.Collection<Option> options,
                                                java.lang.String search)
        Method overload calls find(Collection, String, boolean, double) with default values. boolean returnAll: false, double coverageMultiplier: 0.02975 in the very most cases this overload function is the best option. More info about the Default values can be found at the main function find(Collection, String, boolean, double).
        Parameters:
        options - The Options that should be scanned, use every Collection you like.
        search - The String to be searched for.
        Returns:
        returns a Collection<Option> containing the Results which the Search yielded. Internally all Data is stored using a HashSet<Option>.

      • find

        public static java.util.Collection<Option> find(java.util.Collection<Option> options,
                                                java.lang.String search,
                                                double coverageMultiplier)
        Method overload calls find(Collection, String, boolean, double) with default values. boolean returnAll: false
        Parameters:
        options - The Options that should be scanned, use every Collection you like.
        search - The String to be searched for.
        coverageMultiplier - A value which determines the importance of how much the key of an option covers the search String. A lower value might yield more or better results if you have many keys which can be written differently i.e. Spider-Man and spiderman, but if you need more accurate matches and the coverage is an important factor a higher value might be favorable. A value somewhere in the middle that should work in most cases would be 0.02975 you can also call find(Collection, String) or find(Collection, String, boolean) which use this value by default. You should not use negative values, 0 since they might lead to unexpected behaviour, in most cases values higher than 2 won't achieve better results although higher values are safe. If you're trying to achieve better results it might be worth to play around with this value.
        Returns:
        returns a Collection<Option> containing the Results which the Search yielded. Internally all Data is stored using a HashSet<Option>.

      • find

        public static java.util.Collection<Option> find(java.util.Collection<Option> options,
                                                java.lang.String search,
                                                boolean returnAll)
        Method overload calls find(Collection, String, boolean, double) with default values. double coverageMultiplier: 0.02975 More info about the Default values can be found at the main function find(Collection, String, boolean, double).
        Parameters:
        options - The Options that should be scanned, use every Collection you like.
        search - The String to be searched for.
        returnAll - determines whether if a perfect match for the String was found the program should continue to search. If this value is false and a perfect match was found the Searcher will stop to search and only return the matched value.
        Returns:
        returns a Collection<Option> containing the Results which the Search yielded. Internally all Data is stored using a HashSet<Option>.

      • find

        public static java.util.Collection<Option> find(java.util.Collection<Option> options,
                                                java.lang.String search,
                                                boolean returnAll,
                                                double coverageMultiplier)
        The main Method which is called by the overloading functions. Usually the overloading function which calls this one is the favorable options find(Collection, String) if you prefer to always return all values you can also call find(Collection, String, boolean).
        Parameters:
        options - The Options that should be scanned, use every Collection you like.
        search - The String to be searched for.
        returnAll - determines whether if a perfect match for the String was found the program should continue to search. If this value is false and a perfect match was found the Searcher will stop to search and only return the matched value.
        coverageMultiplier - A value which determines the importance of how much the key of an option covers the search String. A lower value might yield more or better results if you have many keys which can be written differently i.e. Spider-Man and spiderman, but if you need more accurate matches and the coverage is an important factor a higher value might be favorable. A value somewhere in the middle that should work in most cases would be 0.02975 you can also call find(Collection, String) or find(Collection, String, boolean) which use this value by default. You should not use negative values, 0 since they might lead to unexpected behaviour, in most cases values higher than 2 won't achieve better results although higher values are safe. If you're trying to achieve better results it might be worth to play around with this value.
        Returns:
        returns a Collection<Option> containing the Results which the Search yielded. Internally all Data is stored using a HashSet<Option>.
